definition.value: A descriptive qualifier that indicates the nature/extent/availability of an analyte as it was determined in the sample, e.g. dissolved, labile, total etc.
Reference to the oxidation state of an analyte should not be included here as it should be part of the definition of the analyte
The extent of usage of a particular chemical analysis procedure across different industrial sectors, e.g. environmental, pharmaceutical, petrochemical
The fundamental, root unit of a particular measured quantity

Process by which samples are digested by placing them in sealed think-walled glass vials and then placed in a solid heated block.  Typically used in the digestion of sample of Kjeldahl nitrogen analysis.

Process of removal of a solvent by blowing a stream of inert gas across/through a sample, reducing the pressure and causing the solvent to evaporate.  Provides solvent removal without heating a sample.
A property of a composite material made from different chemical entities
A logical set of calculated values, e.g. the slope, intercept and r2 of a calibration curve

The single numeric result datum from a mathematical calculation (or series of mathematical equations) based on measurement data (or previously calculated result(s)) in order to derive property data pertinent to an experiment being conducted.
A material entity that is used to perform a calibration process as part of a chemical analysis
Material entity used to discover the relationship between the magnitude of a detectable chemical or physical property and the concentration of a chemical substance within that material
A set of data from the analysis of a set of standard materials aggregated in order to derive the relationship between the independent and dependent variables.
Metadata categories delineated in the Chemical Analysis Metadata Platform (ChAMP) specification
Processes or procedures performed as part of a chemical analysis activity
A property or characteristic of a chemical entity

A device that measures some property (e.g., receives a stimulus) of the real world and informs (e.g., responds to) its system about the result of the measurement. The lack of a sensor implies a lack of input to the system about the property in question. The sensor is a subsystem for gaining information about the real world. A sensor includes the transducer and the transmitter as part of its design.
A physical process by which a mixture of chemical entities is separated from each other

A graphical or other presentation of detector response, concentration of analyte in the effluent or other quantity used as a measure of effluent concentration versus effluent volume or time. In planar chromatography 'chromatogram' may refer to the paper or layer with the separated zones.
A chemical process by which mixtures of chemical entities are separated by their different partition coefficients between a stationary phase and a liquid phase
Informational items that provide mechanisms to contact an agent
Solution state where a chemical entity has reacted with another chemical entity actig as a ligand to form a complex species
Extent of availability in solution of a chemical substance based on the solid phase based equilibria it is a reactant or product in

The reduction in size of a granular or powdered sample by forming a conical heap which is spread out into a circular, flat cake. The cake is divided radially into quarters and two opposite quarters are combined. The other two quarters are discarded. The process is repeated as many times as necessary to obtain the quantity desired for some final use (e.g. as the laboratory sample or as the test sample). If the process is performed only once, coning and quartering is no more efficient than taking alternate portions and discarding the others.
Charateristics of a numeric value
The label given to a dependent (typically y-axis) axis on a graph. The label normally contains the quantity and its unit
Where chemical analysis apparatus is to be placed
Where an analytical instrument or a wet chemical method is used to detect and/or quantitate an analyte
Small mesh net on a long handle used for captured small aquatic creatures
Process by which a solid chemical entity is dissolved in a solvent
Device that captures a sample from the bottom of a waterbody
Properties of a material related to the flow of electric current through the material
A crystal of a material made from only one type of element, e.g. metals
Has this been defined anywhere elese?

1) A species of atoms; all atoms with the same number of protons in the atomic nucleus.
2) A pure chemical substance composed of atoms with the same number of protons in the atomic nucleus. Sometimes this concept is called the elementary substance as distinct from the chemical element as defined under 1, but mostly the term chemical element is used for both concepts.
A molecular ion that is composed of only one type of element, e.g. triiodide ion (I3-)
Has this been defined anywhere else?
A molecular radical made of only one type of atom, e.g. ozone radical O3
Roles that chemical substances play as part of environment processes
Physical objects that are used in a laboratory to conduct the scientific process that do not generate data to measure and/or record, e.g. autoclave, rotary evaporator, hotplate, ultrasonic bath
The magnitude of number represented in scientific notation

Plot of a detector signal as a function of time in a system where solutions of chemical substances continuously flow, with or without chemical reaction.  There is no 'chromatographic' separation, only presentation of the solutions to the detector using a pump.  Applies to FIA, rFIA, SIA, merging zones, and flow cytometry techniques.

A predetermined procedure for the selection, withdrawal, preservation, transportation and preparation of the portions to be removed from a population as samples. Summarizing the test values or observations from the selected portions yields an estimate for the concentration of an analyte or a value for a property determined with a calculable degree of uncertainty at a specified confidence level. A sampling plan includes the designation of the number, location and size of the portions, and instructions for the extent of compositing and for the reduction (in amount and fineness) of the portions to a laboratory sample and to test portions. It may also contain acceptance criteria. Some sampling plans do not include more than instructions for the statistical selection of portions to be removed. Such plans should properly be designated as 'statistical sampling plans'.

An qualifier that presents information about the quality or appropriateness of a chemical analysis relative to its intended purpose.  Intended to convey a measure of the scope of application relative to other chemical analysis methods.
Chemical test used to determine the presence or absence of an organic functional group
Device with a plastic bottle on the end of a long pole used for taking subsurface water samples from the side of bodies of water
Person in charge of group of research scientists

The process of taking a sample of the gas phase (headspace) above a sample in a closed vessel (e.g. vial) after it has equilibrated.  Used in gas chromatography to avoid injection of solvent and/or matrix components that may degrade the analytical performance of the chromatographic system.
The process of increasing the temperature of a solution by application of heating in order to increase the rate of dissolution of one or more chemical entities
A material where two or more substances and mixed together but the composition is different in different parts of the material
A mixture where all substances are intimately mixed such that the composition of the material is uniform throughout
Two or more discrete analytical instruments that are interfaced together (providing transfer of analyte(s)) to produce a device that can be considered a analytical instrument in-of-itself
The label given to an independent (typically x-axis) axis on a graph. The label normally contains the quantity and its unit
A chemical substance introduced into a reaction system in order to bring about an initiation reaction.
